==== 2 February ====
==== 2 February ====
{{Copy edit|section|date=February 2011}}
{{Copy edit|section|date=February 2011}}
â
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, armed with clubs, stones, rocks and knives, attacked protesters in central Cairo, including Tahrir square.<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters are coming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] is sending hundreds of activists to show support to Hosni Mubarak.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} The army was asking the protesters to go home.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
+
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria; shots were reportedly fired in the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive">{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 2 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs sent by the Egyptian government, armed with clubs, stones, rocks and knives, attacked protesters in central Cairo, including Tahrir square.<ref>{{Cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarakâs Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many of the protesters from the previous day's protest decided to sleep and remain in Tahrir Square while more protesters are coming.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html</ref> The army was asking the protesters to go home.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> There was also unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Private [[mercenaries]] were also said to be in Egypt to evacuate foreigners.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who are the pro-Mubarak demonstrators? - CNN.com |publisher=CNN |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
At noon local time, internet access in Egypt has been at least partially restored and the night-time curfew in Egypt has been eased. It will now run from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=BBC News |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Curfew hours were shortened to 5:00 pm to 7:00 am the next day.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/> The pro-Mubarak activists attacked [[Al Arabiya]] reporter Ahmed Bagato while he was trying to show them harassing the anti-Mubarak protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt protests: live |publisher=Telegraph |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive"/><ref name="aljazlive">''Al Jazeera English''. Breaking News. 2 February 2011. 16:00</ref>
